page.name: Resources
page.content:
You have explored the IET Toolkit content and structure and have become familiar with the phases of IET design. We will end the course with an overview of some of the other resources available to support IET planning and implementation. After you finish reviewing the resources, return to the main course page to review the Unit Summary.

Interactive version of the IET Design Toolkit

  • In this module, you explored the PDF version of the IET Design Toolkit.  An interactive version is available through the LINCS Learning Portal, that you logged into in order to access this IET Fundamentals Course. The content of the interactive version is identical to the PDF content, but it offers hyperlinks to supplementary websites and provides downloadable Word versions of the tools and templates. Scroll down the IET Design Toolkit landing page to the section called "Abstract" to find the url to the Interactive version. 
IET Design Train the Trainer Resources

  • This is a comprehensive set of professional development resources developed for the Basic Design Camps from the Increasing IET Opportunities for Adults Project (2019 -2022). They include an IET Design Camp Training Guide, PowerPoint presentations, and handouts that can be used and customized for local and state professional development purposes. 

Resources from ADVANCE IET

  • The ADVANCE IET project builds on the increasing IET Opportunities for Adult Project and will provide states and programs with training and technical assistance to develop, strengthen, and scale IET programs that effectively support diverse adult learner pathways to high-quality careers. Check this webpage for newly developed resources from ADVANCE IET, such as:
  • IET Quality Indicators, a tool for supporting program development and continuous improvement. 
  • IET Repository of freely available resources that support IET planning, design, and implementation.
  • Online professional development courses (this course is the first in a series of three).
  • Summaries of specialized IET models. 
  • …and more!

Integrated Education and Training: Implementing Programs in Diverse Contexts

  • This publication features eight examples of IET programs from which practitioners can draw ideas and inspiration. It was intentionally developed with an emphasis on “diverse contexts” to offer profiles of IET programs in rural and urban areas, of varied sizes,  implemented in both community-based organizations and community college settings. Units 1 and 2 of this course draw on some of the profiles in this report.

Integrated Education and Training (IET) in Corrections: A Companion Guide to the IET Design Toolkit 

  • This guide summarizes lessons learned from the IET in Corrections project and serves as a companion to the IET Design Toolkit. It offers considerations, tools, and examples for planning, designing, implementing, and evaluating IET programs in prisons and jails, designed to supplement the guidance provided in the Toolkit.

Compendium of Innovative Practices: Adult Education Bridge Programs and Integrated Education and Training (IET) Programs

  • This publication features profiles of five adult education programs that are implementing Bridge and IET programs. Bridge programs, according to the compendium are distinct from IET programs in that they do not include an occupational training component. Rather, the intention is to allow learners to enroll in postsecondary education and training upon completion of the Bridge.  Both the Bridge and IET programs featured in the compendium implement common practices, such as partnerships with local employers and workforce development agencies, workforce preparation, and contextualized basic skills instruction.
Return to the main course page to review the Unit Summary.
